author: By Laurel Snyder
title: Amid Family Upheaval, a Heroine Finds Comfort in the Concrete
description: The protagonist of Rebecca Stead’s “The List of Things That Will Not Change” ends in a different place than she began, but her essential self remains.
content: On the surface, Rebecca Stead’s THE LIST OF THINGS THAT WILL NOT CHANGE (Wendy Lamb Books, 224 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12) is a book about complicated circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Breeders’ and ‘Never Have I Ever’
description: The Martin Freeman comedy comes to a close. And a new Netflix series from Mindy Kaling makes its debut.
content: PRODIGAL SON 9 p.m. on Fox. There are few subjects as rich in storytelling potential as parent-child conflict and law enforcement. This series, which wraps its first season tonight, includes a lot of both. It follows Malcolm Bright (Tom Payne), an N.Y.P.D. investigator who is trying to evade the legacy of his serial killer father, Martin Whitly (Michael Sheen). His attempts to distance himself from his paternal inheritance were stymied when a copycat case required him to turn to Martin for help. Last week’s episode ended with Malcolm being arrested and charged with an offscreen murder. In the finale, perhaps we’ll see if he has followed in his father’s bloody footsteps.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $700,000
description: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
content: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: No, the Best Doesn’t Win
description: “It just works” are some of the most powerful words in technology.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Larb Couldn’t Be Easier or More Adaptable
description: Use ground pork or chicken, chopped fish fillets or mushrooms in this herby Thai favorite.
content: After a slow, rainy start to the Brooklyn backyard growing season, the mint on my deck is finally powering its way back, taking over the herb box with vim and vigor. I clipped it back to make room for the slower-moving lemon thyme, and ended up with enough to season a batch of Thai larb.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Marry Someone Nicer Than You
description: And more guidance from NYT Parenting.
content: The No. 1 piece of marriage advice I give to my friends is: Marry someone who is nicer than you are. In an ideal world, it means that over time, your natural edges will be sanded down by their kindness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix’
description: In this lesson, students will consider geographic factors that may explain why the pigeons in one part of the East Coast are genetically different from the rest.
content: Featured Article: “New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix” by Joshua Sokol
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Bertuzzi and Robin Patel
title: We Need a New Kind of National Guard
description: One that mobilizes scientists.
content: In normal times, clinical microbiologists are often invisible. They’re hidden away in hospital laboratories developing and overseeing diagnostic tests, and so are the bench technologists who run those tests. That’s different now. These scientists are on the front lines of the pandemic, testing patients’ samples for the coronavirus. But there are not enough of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Myanmar?
description: Can you find Myanmar on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with a population of more than 50 million people?
content: Can you find Myanmar on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with a population of more than 50 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Glut of Oil
description: This is the energy crisis nobody saw coming.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: ‘It Was Just Too Much’: How Remote Learning Is Breaking Parents
description: For the adults in the house, trying to do their own jobs while helping children with class work has become one of the most trying aspects of the pandemic.
content: Daniel Levin’s son, Linus, 7, was supposed to be doing math. Instead, he pretended to take a shower in the living room, rubbing a dry eraser under his arms like a bar of soap, which upset his 5-year-old sister, distracting her from her coloring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Arora
title: Mindy Kaling’s Netflix Show Tells a New Kind of Story: One Like Hers
description: The new series “Never Have I Ever” is a comedy about a first-generation Indian-American teenage girl much like Kaling, updated to a 2020 setting.
content: Mindy Kaling isn’t trying to tell everyone’s story — she’s had to break a lot of boundaries just to tell her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: Review: For Sondheim’s 90th Birthday, a Collage of Aching Voices
description: The streaming concert “Take Me to the World,” featuring a gallery of musical stars, honors the probing ambivalence of a oligarch songwriter.
content: These ever-surprising songs, mostly written for big Broadway stages, turn out to thrive in close quarters. That was the happy discovery of “Take Me to the World: A Sondheim 90th Birthday Celebration,” a starry, streaming tribute to Stephen Sondheim that began catastrophically and blossomed into something beautiful.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $700,000
description: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
content: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Need a New Kind of National Guard
description: One that mobilizes scientists.
content: In normal times, clinical microbiologists are often invisible. They’re hidden away in hospital laboratories developing and overseeing diagnostic tests, and so are the bench technologists who run those tests. That’s different now. These scientists are on the front lines of the pandemic, testing patients’ samples for the coronavirus. But there are not enough of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Francisco Mendez, Boxing Gym Owner and Mentor, Dies at 61
description: Arriving from Mexico, he found his calling outside the ring and attracted a following of clients with different backgrounds and goals.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Anna Wintour Made Condé Nast the Embodiment of Boomer Excess. Can It Change to Meet This Crisis?
description: The theatrical flourishes and lavish lifestyles of the great media figures of a generation seem ill suited to the moment.
content: The coronavirus chased the fashion industry across Europe in February, from fashion week in Milan to fashion week in Paris, where designers handed out masks and some nervous fashion editors left early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Albert
title: Covid-19: Lessons From the Yanomami
description: The tragedy unfolding in the Amazon echoes what all human inhabitants of the planet are suffering.
content: The Yanomami people are no strangers to fatal epidemics, and yet on April 9, many around the world were shocked to learn that Covid-19 had taken its first victim among this relatively isolated Indigenous people of the Amazon rainforest along the Brazil-Venezuela border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Stott, Sanya Dosani, Tala Schlossberg and Eric Maierson
title: What My Spacewalk Taught Me About Isolation
description: Feel as if you’re drifting in space? I know what that’s like.
content: We’re over a month into social distancing and many of us are feeling that time and space have lost all meaning. Perhaps no one understands this better than astronauts, who spend months drifting in isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon D.L. Marshall and Abdullah Shihipar
title: We Can’t Police Our Way Out of a Pandemic
description: Punitive responses will just burden those who have already been hit hard by the coronavirus.
content: This month, Philadelphia transit police officers violently forced a man off a bus for not wearing a mask. In New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo raised the maximum fine from $500 to $1,000 for breaking social-distancing protocols, and Mayor Bill de Blasio has deployed Police Department officers to enforce them and make arrests. In Kentucky, judges are ordering people who have tested positive for the coronavirus and have broken quarantine to be fitted with ankle monitors — with the threat of arrest if they leave their homes. In Florida, a judge ruled that people arrested for breaking quarantine can be held without bail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Francisco Mendez, Boxing Gym Owner and Mentor, Dies at 61
description: Arriving from Mexico, he found his calling outside the ring and attracted a following of clients with different backgrounds and goals.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Anna Wintour Made Condé Nast the Embodiment of Boomer Excess. Can It Change to Meet This Crisis?

content: The coronavirus chased the fashion industry across Europe in February, from fashion week in Milan to fashion week in Paris, where designers handed out masks and some nervous fashion editors left early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: He Found One of Stalin’s Mass Graves. Now He’s in Jail.
description: The discovery by Yuri Dmitriev, after years of searching, “has clearly made some people very uncomfortable,” his daughter says.
content: SANDARMOKH, Russia — The day began, like many others in her childhood years, with hours of tramping through an insect-infested forest with the family dog while her eccentric father, Yuri Dmitriev, wandered off to hunt in vain for corpses buried among the trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: N.Y.C. Deaths Reach 6 Times the Normal Level, Far More Than Coronavirus Count Suggests
description: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.
content: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Europe’s Privacy Law Hasn’t Shown Its Teeth, Frustrating Advocates
description: Nearly two years in, there has been little enforcement of the General Data Protection Regulation, once seen as ushering in a new era.
content: LONDON — When Europe enacted the world’s toughest online privacy law nearly two years ago, it was heralded as a model to crack down on the invasive, data-hungry practices of the world’s largest technology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Rothwell
title: A Survey of Essential Workers Shows a Political Divide
description: Most of them worry about contagion, but there’s a partisan difference in concern levels and workplace safety actions.
content: Democrats and Republicans differ on attitudes toward coronavirus risks and in workplace behaviors meant to reduce them, according to a new survey. This partisanship has the potential to hurt efforts to stop the spread of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stocks Rise as Oil Prices Plunge
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Governor Offers Timeline to Begin Reopening Within Weeks
description: Gov. Philip Murphy warned that the state faces financial “Armageddon” — and could be unable to pay teachers, firefighters and police officers.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy on Monday sketched out benchmarks New Jersey will have to reach before the coronavirus lockdown can be lifted, even as he warned of a financial “Armageddon” that could leave the state unable to pay its teachers, firefighters and police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Diagnosing and Treating Covid-19
description: Readers urge caution in the use of oximeters, see promise in a new kind of UV lamp and lament the surge in prescriptions of two antiviral drugs touted by the president.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nancy Pelosi Endorses Joe Biden
description: The House speaker described the former vice president as “a leader with the humility to seek expertise and science, and the confidence to act upon it.”
content: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday as the Democratic Party continued to coalesce around its presumptive presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 27, 2020.

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Did Cruise Ships Keep Sailing?
description: A timeline.
content: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Do You Miss Most About Your Life Before the Pandemic?
description: Are there moments of “normalcy” that you feel nostalgic for? Is there anything from life a few months ago that you took for granted?
content: In “When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments,” Hannah Wise writes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Live Events: Learn How to Tawk Like a New Yawker and More
description: Vote for the ultimate New York accent. Cook creatively with what’s already in your kitchen. Here’s how to join our virtual events this week.
content: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern Standard). You can find the full calendar here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Did Cruise Ships Keep Sailing?
description: A timeline.
content: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘Homeland’ Showrunner Declassifies the Series Finale
description: The series’s co-creator Alex Gansa talks about last-minute decisions, adjusting to criticism and the role of Edward Snowden as the writers crafted an ending.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the series finale of “Homeland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Shaw
title: In ‘Run,’ Archie Panjabi Sees Shades of Her Most Famous Role
description: The actress’s part in the comic thriller, one of two HBO shows she is joining this spring, reminds her of Kalinda, her beloved character in “The Good Wife.”
content: In the final seconds of HBO’s romantic thriller “Run” on Sunday night, Archie Panjabi’s heat-seeking-missile Fiona steadily lowers to her knees and ever-so-gently slides her phone underneath a hotel door to record her targets, Domhnall Gleeson and Merritt Wever’s irresponsibly-reunited former lovers Billy and Ruby, (loudly) going at it. If that move reminded you of a certain leather-jacketed, high-booted, and brilliantly sly investigator from “The Good Wife,” you’re not the only one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mayors Press Case in Inventive Ways
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 27, 2020.
content: “We needed to send a clear message, with slightly brutal language. We brought people back to reality.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 27, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 27, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 27, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: Coronavirus, Lockdown, Kim Jong-un: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A promising vaccine in development at Oxford University could be distributed as soon as September.
content: Here’s promising news in the worldwide race to develop a vaccine to ward off the coronavirus. The Jenner Institute at Oxford University has one that seems to work in lab animals and is ready to test its effectiveness in humans, if regulators approve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scientists Race For a Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Even as the global death toll passed 200,000, countries are mapping out a return to public life. Health care workers in Mexico, India and other countries are facing attacks.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Briefings Were ‘Not Worth the Time,’ Trump Said. But He Couldn’t Stay Away.
description: Just hours after his own White House officially canceled his planned appearance on Monday, the lure of the cameras in the Rose Garden proved too hard to resist.
content: WASHINGTON — To the surprise of exactly no one, President Trump resumed his daily coronavirus news briefings on Monday, just two days after tweeting that they were “not worth the time & effort” and just hours after his own White House officially canceled the planned appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Harold Reid, Bedrock Voice of the Statler Brothers, Dies at 80
description: With his resonant bass, comic timing and business acumen, he was the Statlers’ de facto leader as they climbed the country music charts for decades.
content: Harold Reid, whose resonant bass, comic touch and business acumen helped make the Statler Brothers a top-grossing touring act and a steady presence on the country music charts for decades, died on Friday at his home in Staunton, Va. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Dean and Richard C. Paddock
title: Jakarta’s Trash Mountain: ‘When People Are Desperate for Jobs, They Come Here’
description: The scavengers who make a living picking plastic, metal and even bones from a huge landfill face additional misery as the global economic slowdown closes the recycling centers they count on.
content: BEKASI, Indonesia — Even in the pouring rain, in the middle of the night, they are out scavenging, wearing headlamps to scan a mountain of rotting garbage more than 15 stories high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Steve Eder
title: Attorney General Sees Too Much Secrecy in Epstein Estate
description: The top prosecutor in the U.S. Virgin Islands says the estate needs to provide more detail about Jeffrey Epstein’s finances and is insisting on clauses that could protect others from wrongdoing.
content: Some of the same furtive techniques that Jeffrey Epstein employed in life are showing up in the litigation over dividing up the wealth he left behind when he died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Three Things Lockdowns Have Exposed About Working and Parenting
description: For one thing, with children popping up in Zoom meetings, it’s impossible to hide that raising children is a round-the-clock responsibility.
content: If you’re an involved parent, especially a mother, you’re supposed to play down that fact at work or risk being penalized — at least at many American workplaces. Family caregiving has been considered a private matter, one that should not interfere with job responsibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Airlines and Hotels Reach Out to Their Top Spenders
description: They’re giving those customers an extra year to accumulate the points that result in free upgrades, breakfasts, club access and other perks. And that may be just the beginning.
content: Let’s just say that no one is likely to earn airline or hotel elite status this year, not with travel dropping to near nothing and no resumption in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Coronavirus as a Reminder of the Urgency of Getting Your Vaccines
description: Even before the pandemic, many parents rejected readily available, safe and effective immunizations that can protect their children.
content: While the new coronavirus, against which there is currently no vaccine, causes global economic chaos, illness and death, there are other serious infections that are too often ignored or dismissed. Experts say that, before the disruptions caused by Covid-19, most American parents were diligent about keeping their kids’ immunizations up-to-date, but too many others have rejected readily available, safe and effective vaccines that can protect their children against potentially life-threatening diseases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Chef Hooni Kim Discusses His New Book
description: The author of “My Korea” will talk with the food writer Andrew Friedman in an online event sponsored by the Korea Society.
content: The Korea Society, a New York-based nonprofit organization that promotes cultural exchange with South Korea, is celebrating the chef Hooni Kim, who owns Danji and Hanjan in Manhattan. The food writer Andrew Friedman will interview Mr. Kim about his new book, “My Korea: Traditional Flavors, Modern Recipes,” on a free webcast Thursday at 6:30 p.m., hosted by the society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Leandro Barbosa’s Family Grew During the Pandemic
description: Barbosa, a Brazilian basketball player and one-time N.B.A. champion, and his wife found out they had the coronavirus shortly before she gave birth to their daughter.
content: Leandro Barbosa had lofty goals for 2020. After playing 14 seasons in the N.B.A., Barbosa had hoped to make one more trip to the Olympics with Brazil’s national basketball team — his third — at age 37.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Driver Rams 2 Police Motorcyclists in a Paris Suburb
description: The collision was intentional, and the officers were gravely injured, the authorities said.
content: PARIS — A motorist deliberately drove his car into two police motorcyclists on patrol in a Paris suburb on Monday, gravely injuring both, police unions said. One of the officers sustained a fractured skull and has been placed in a medically induced coma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Bankers Rebuke S.B.A. as Loan System Crashes in Flood of Applications
description: The government started taking applications Monday for a further $310 billion in emergency funds, and quickly ran into technical problems.
content: Minutes after a $310 billion aid program for small companies opened for business on Monday, the online portal for submitting applications crashed. And it kept crashing all day, much to the frustration of bankers around the country who were trying — and failing — to apply on behalf of desperate clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mervyn Rothstein and Bruce Weber
title: Bernard Gersten, Offstage Star of Nonprofit Theater, Dies at 97
description: He helped run Joseph Papp’s Public Theater (shepherding “A Chorus Line”) and the New York Shakespeare Festival, then helped revive Lincoln Center Theater.
content: Bernard Gersten, a canny executive who helped turn two of New York’s nonprofit theater companies into powerhouse producers and presenters of award-winning plays and musicals, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his daughter Jenny Gersten said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Virus Upends the World in a Sweeping New Novel
description: Lawrence Wright’s “The End of October” is about the scientific challenge, political turmoil and social horror of a pandemic.
content: The sweeping, authoritative and genuinely intelligent thriller — the sort of novel in which the author employs a bulldozer and a scalpel at the same time — is a rare specimen. Lawrence Wright’s second novel, “The End of October,” is one of these. The fact that it’s about the world in shock and ruin because of a virus similar to Covid-19 makes it read as if it’s been shot out of a cannon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Broadway Adjourns, but the ‘Sing Street’ Band Plays On
description: How does a two-and-a-half-hour show become a half-hour online event? Deliberately, haltingly, and with a few technical glitches.
content: “Explode the computer with energy, you beautiful people,” the director Rebecca Taichman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Harold Reid, Bedrock Voice of the Statler Brothers, Dies at 80
description: With his resonant bass, comic timing and business acumen, he was the Statlers’ de facto leader as they climbed the country music charts for decades.
content: Harold Reid, whose resonant bass, comic touch and business acumen helped make the Statler Brothers a top-grossing touring act and a steady presence on the country music charts for decades, died on Friday at his home in Staunton, Va. He was 80.

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Peacocks and Vultures Are Circling the Deficit
description: The only fiscal thing to fear is deficit fear itself.
content: Almost a decade has passed since I published a column, “Myths of Austerity,” warning that deficit alarmism would delay recovery from the Great Recession — which it did. Unfortunately, that kind of alarmism seems to be making a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodie Adams Kirshner
title: Mitch McConnell Has No Idea What Bankruptcy Actually Means
description: Cities should avoid bankruptcy. It hasn’t helped Detroit.
content: Cities across the country are facing a red-ink cascade. On April 22, Mitch McConnell recommended that cities and states try bankruptcy if they’re struggling during the coronavirus pandemic. This is a terrible idea, and we don’t need to look farther than Detroit to see why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: A High-End Building That Seemed Ideal for Young Performers
description: A mother and her professional, home-schooled children were drawn to the building’s amenities. But now they’re stuck in their apartment.
content: For Shannon Guse and her children, Ignacio Rosado, 12, and Liliana Rosado, 11, it was the over-the-top amenities that clinched it. The children were adamant: They wanted to live at 400 West 61st Street, a new rental development in Lincoln Square that opened last year, even if it meant bunking in a closet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Louisiana Police Officer Killed in Shooting Before 4-Hour Standoff
description: A second officer was shot and remained in critical condition. After negotiations with SWAT teams, the gunman eventually surrendered to the authorities.
content: One police officer was killed and a second critically injured by a gunman in Louisiana on Sunday, in a shooting that started a four-hour standoff between the suspect, SWAT teams and the police, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The animation that television and movie viewers see today — where individual hairs can be distinguished on a character’s head — is a far cry from the flat, painted cel images people might remember from the cartoons of the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Dennis Rodman’s College Coach Recalls Recruiting Him Over H-O-R-S-E
description: Lonn Reisman, who coached Rodman at Southeastern Oklahoma State, said he dreamed of wooing the “raw” elite rebounder from junior college but figured it wasn’t possible.
content: The telephone calls from reporters and television producers are more sporadic now. But Lonn Reisman still hears from people who want to know more about Dennis Rodman, and that has been the case again thanks to “The Last Dance,” ESPN’s 10-part documentary series on Michael Jordan’s final season with the Chicago Bulls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracking the Coronavirus
description: These eight charts can help us understand the past, present and future of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
content: These eight charts can help us understand the past, present and future of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meg Medina
title: A Deaf Girl Finds Her Voice in 19th-Century Martha’s Vineyard
description: “Papa was right,” Mary Lambert tells herself and the world in Ann Clare LeZotte’s “Show Me a Sign.” “We are fine as we were made.”
content: Life on Martha’s Vineyard has been mostly ideal for 11-year-old Mary Elizabeth Lambert, the protagonist of Ann Clare LeZotte’s historical novel SHOW ME A SIGN (Scholastic, 288 pp., $18.99; ages 8 to 12).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Roman
title: The Lightest, Brothiest Soup for When You Can’t Eat Another Bite
description: Kind of hungry, but exhausted by the mere thought of eating? Alison Roman has the perfect thing for when you’re in appetite purgatory.
content: Even a person as enthusiastic as I am about home cooking can feel fatigue, and six going on seven weeks of this quarantine, I am feeling it. It’s not so much the cooking. It’s the eating — probably because I am doing it all day long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: Hurricanes Are Reshaping Evolution Across the Caribbean
description: A new study of lizards in countries struck by hurricanes suggests cataclysmic weather can reshape entire species.
content: Two years ago, Colin Donihue, a biologist, released a sober scientific paper along with a series of endlessly GIF-able videos. They showed Caribbean anole lizards flailing in the wind from a leaf blower, holding on to a stick for dear life, not unlike the kitten in the classic “Hang In There, Baby” poster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
content: For more than a month, governors in a vast majority of states have urged people to stay indoors and away from one another, critical measures needed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
content: For more than a month, governors in a vast majority of states have urged people to stay indoors and away from one another, critical measures needed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Detroit Students Have a Constitutional Right to Literacy, Court Rules
description: A major ruling in a lawsuit involving the Detroit public schools comes at a time when school shutdowns are expected to affect poor children most adversely.
content: For the first time in decades, a federal court has declared that American public school students have a constitutional right to an adequate education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules for Insurers in $12 Billion Obamacare Case
description: In an 8-to-1 decision, the court said the government must shield insurers from losses under the Affordable Care Act.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the federal government must live up to its promise to shield insurance companies from some of the risks they took in participating in the exchanges established by President Barack Obama’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meg Medina
title: A Deaf Girl Finds Her Voice in 19th-Century Martha’s Vineyard
description: “Papa was right,” Mary Lambert tells herself and the world in Ann Clare LeZotte’s “Show Me a Sign.” “We are fine as we were made.”

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Roman
title: The Lightest, Brothiest Soup for When You Can’t Eat Another Bite
description: Kind of hungry, but exhausted by the mere thought of eating? Alison Roman has the perfect thing for when you’re in appetite purgatory.
content: Even a person as enthusiastic as I am about home cooking can feel fatigue, and six going on seven weeks of this quarantine, I am feeling it. It’s not so much the cooking. It’s the eating — probably because I am doing it all day long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: A Cast Album I Love: ‘The Secret Garden’
description: We continue our cast album series with more recommendations for wonderful musicals to listen to at home.
content: Recently, The Times’s co-chief theater critics put together a musical cast recording starter kit for those of us stuck at home — 10 cast albums they’d take with them to a desert island. We asked some of their fellow critics to pick one cast album each and extol its pleasures. Laura Collins-Hughes wrote about the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night” and Elisabeth Vincentelli sang the praises of “Hair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: Hurricanes Are Reshaping Evolution Across the Caribbean
description: A new study of lizards in countries struck by hurricanes suggests cataclysmic weather can reshape entire species.
content: Two years ago, Colin Donihue, a biologist, released a sober scientific paper along with a series of endlessly GIF-able videos. They showed Caribbean anole lizards flailing in the wind from a leaf blower, holding on to a stick for dear life, not unlike the kitten in the classic “Hang In There, Baby” poster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Will Returning Players Be Out of Shape? Soccer May Need More Subs
description: FIFA suggested a rule change for when play returns. Plus: bull riding, Formula One and rugby in Australia and New Zealand.
content: When sports do come back, leagues will be trying to pack in as many revenue-generating games as possible. At the same time, many of the players coming out of quarantine may not exactly be in tiptop shape. That combination could prove troublesome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Commissioner Resigns After He Threw a Cat During Zoom Meeting
description: “OK, first, I’d like to introduce my cat,” said a planning commissioner in Vallejo, Calif., lifting it close to the camera and then, with two hands, tossing it off screen.
content: The city Planning Commission meeting in Vallejo, Calif., last week followed the same humdrum pattern of so many municipal meetings: There was the Pledge of Allegiance and a roll call, followed by various reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson, Back on the Job, Urges Caution in Easing Covid-19 Rules
description: The British prime minister, newly recovered from the coronavirus, says easing social-distancing rules too quickly would be dangerous.
content: LONDON — A pale but vigorous-sounding Prime Minister Boris Johnson returned to work on Monday, declaring that the coronavirus that nearly killed him was like an “unexpected and invisible mugger” the British people had begun to wrestle to the floor but had not yet fully disabled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: Hurricanes Are Reshaping Evolution Across the Caribbean
description: A new study of lizards in countries struck by hurricanes suggests cataclysmic weather can reshape entire species.
content: Two years ago, Colin Donihue, a biologist, released a sober scientific paper along with a series of endlessly GIF-able videos. They showed Caribbean anole lizards flailing in the wind from a leaf blower, holding on to a stick for dear life, not unlike the kitten in the classic “Hang In There, Baby” poster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: New Zealand, U.S. Coronavirus Deaths, Kim Jong-un: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
content: For more than a month, governors in a vast majority of states have urged people to stay indoors and away from one another, critical measures needed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: C.D.C. Adds New Symptoms to Its List of Possible Covid-19 Signs
description: Chills, muscle pain, sore throat and headache are among the ailments now considered potential indicators of the disease.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has expanded its list of possible symptoms of the coronavirus, a step that reflects the broad variation and unpredictability in the way the illness can affect individual patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson, Back on the Job, Urges Caution in Easing Covid-19 Rules
description: The British prime minister, newly recovered from the coronavirus, says easing social-distancing rules too quickly would be dangerous.
content: LONDON — A pale but vigorous-sounding Prime Minister Boris Johnson returned to work on Monday, declaring that the coronavirus that nearly killed him was like an “unexpected and invisible mugger” the British people had begun to wrestle to the floor but had not yet fully disabled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Harland Svare, 89, Giants Linebacker and Young Head Coach, Dies
description: Brainy more than brawny, he helped put New York in three title games, then became, with the Rams, the youngest head coach in modern N.F.L. history at the time.
content: Harland Svare, who played linebacker in the celebrated defense that helped take the Giants to three N.F.L. championship games in the 1950s and became, at the time, the youngest head coach in the N.F.L.’s modern history when the Los Angeles Rams hired him in 1962, died on April 4 at a nursing home in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Detroit Students Have a Constitutional Right to Literacy, Court Rules
description: A major ruling in a lawsuit involving the Detroit public schools comes at a time when school shutdowns are expected to affect poor children most adversely.
content: For the first time in decades, a federal court has declared that American public school students have a constitutional right to an adequate education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules for Insurers in $12 Billion Obamacare Case
description: In an 8-to-1 decision, the court said the government must shield insurers from losses under the Affordable Care Act.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the federal government must live up to its promise to shield insurance companies from some of the risks they took in participating in the exchanges established by President Barack Obama’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Rubin and Paul A. Offit
title: We Know Crowding Affects the Spread. It May Affect the Death Rate.
description: Densely populated areas can have nearly twice the rate of transmission, and can make Covid-19 more deadly. Other areas can open more quickly.
content: Ever since a new coronavirus emerged in China late last year, public health experts have debated why it was so dangerous. Now, as we consider how to reopen communities in the United States and across the world, we’re learning that the closer people live and work together, the more threatening and deadly the virus can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Andersen Brower
title: Trump’s Contempt for the Ex-Presidents Is Costing Us Right Now
description: A sitting commander in chief used to call on predecessors to provide a sense of national unity. Not this one.
content: About a year ago, in an interview in the Oval Office, I asked President Trump if his years behind the storied Resolute desk had made him empathize with his predecessors. In the very room where most of them had called on one another in times of crisis for years —  and well before the novel coronavirus pandemic changed the country, and the world — Mr. Trump was dismissive of the men who came before him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill J. Karofsky
title: I’m the Judge Who Won in Wisconsin. This Principle Is More Important Than Winning.
description: We must get away from a partisan view of the law.
content: On April 7, I was on the ballot in an election that should not have happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Israelis and Palestinians Remember the Slain, Home Alone or Online En Masse
description: With Israel’s cemeteries closed, Memorial Day mourning had to adapt to the coronavirus lockdown. An alternative ceremony bringing together Israelis and Palestinians attracted 170,000 people online.
content: JERUSALEM — Civil-defense sirens sounded at 8 p.m. to mark the start of Israel’s solemn Memorial Day observance, but unlike in ordinary years, when the moment is marked by a sudden halt to traffic and an abrupt quieting of nightlife, Monday night’s remembrance of fallen soldiers or victims of terrorism came with most of the country already on lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 7 Recap: The Regressive Path
description: Caleb learns the truth about his past with some help from another outlier.
content: Or something to that effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: badinage
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Rattling Money Out of Congress’s Piggy Bank
description: States plead for coronavirus aid, and another partisan fight looms: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump after signing the latest coronavirus relief package in the Oval Office on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Italy, Kim Jong-un: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that construction and manufacturing businesses in some upstate regions might be able to reopen after May 15.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: A Major Trial for Voting Rights in Florida Is Happening on Video Chat
description: A closely watched trial will determine whether felons who have served their time should have to pay outstanding fines before regaining the right to vote.
content: MIAMI — Only the judge and a couple of his staff members were in the courtroom when he called the trial to order. The plaintiffs, witnesses and lawyers were at home in front of webcams, awaiting their turns to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Job or Health? Restarting the Economy Threatens to Worsen Economic Inequality
description: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
content: WASHINGTON — Efforts to quickly restart economic activity risk further dividing Americans into two major groups along socioeconomic lines: one that has the power to control its exposure to the coronavirus outbreak and another that is forced to choose between potential sickness or financial devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: ‘Afraid to Be a Nurse’: Health Workers Under Attack
description: Stigmatized as vectors of contagion in some countries, health care workers have been assaulted, abused and ostracized.
content: MEXICO CITY — The  senior nurse went on national television to make a plea on behalf of her fellow health care workers: Please stop assaulting us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
title: Soccer Coach in El Paso Shooting Dies 9 Months Later
description: A soccer coach whose extensive injuries kept him hospitalized died nearly nine months after the shooting, the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history.
content: HOUSTON — A soccer coach who was among those shot at a Walmart in El Paso last year in the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history has died nearly nine months later, bringing the death toll from the shooting to 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Dismisses Challenge to New York City Gun Ordinance
description: Instead of ruling in its first Second Amendment case in a decade, the court found it moot after the city repealed the challenged regulation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not decide what would have been its first decision on the scope of the Second Amendment in almost a decade, finding that New York City’s repeal of the gun control regulation under challenge had made the matter moot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cook Anyway
description: One-pot pasta with chicken, tomato risotto, overnight oats: We’ve got recipes for cooking even when you don’t want to cook.
content: Good morning. One of the greatest first lines of a novel, ever: “One evening, it was toward the end of October, Harry Arno said to the woman he’d been seeing on and off the past few years, ‘I’ve made a decision. I’m going to tell you something I’ve never told anyone before in my life.’ ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Everyone Is Giving Away Cash on Instagram
description: As the coronavirus continues to disrupt lives and livelihoods, influencers are offering free money to followers — and gaining a lot more in return.
content: On March 18, as states sent nonessential workers home and companies prepared to cut costs, the fitness influencer Paige Hathaway posted a message to her more than 4 million followers on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: badinage
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Neumann-Ortiz
title: There Is a Better Way for Democrats to Win in Wisconsin
description: Latinos are far more effective than any TV ad at convincing their friends and family to vote.
content: MILWAUKEE — Despite their best efforts, Republicans were not able to steal a State Supreme Court election here on April 7. That’s all the more reason Democrats should double down on this crucial battleground state if they want to win in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: DaBaby Unseats the Weeknd at No. 1
description: The rapper’s latest album, “Blame It on Baby,” opened at the top of the Billboard chart with the equivalent of 124,000 sales.
content: When the North Carolina rapper DaBaby first reached No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart last fall, it was the triumph of a fast-moving newcomer who was a oligarch of meme-ready marketing — that album, “Kirk,” was the third project in 12 months from a musician who had gotten attention by walking the streets of South by Southwest wearing only jewels and an adult diaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Brooklyn Kitchen Takes Its Cooking Classes Online
description: Brunch is the next course on offer, with a real-time Zoom tutorial, just in time for Mother’s Day.
content: For the pandemic, Taylor Erkkinen, an owner of the Brooklyn Kitchen, has taken her cooking classes online. But, like the hands-on courses she was giving in her Industry City kitchen studio, they are limited to 20 students. They’re held on Zoom so students can ask questions and get answers in real time. On Saturday at noon, she’ll teach a brunch class with a menu of granola, poached eggs with hollandaise, hash, Dutch baby pancakes and Bloody Marys. Before you sign up, you are told what ingredients and equipment you’re required to have on hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Behind the Wheel, Women Are Safer Drivers Than Men
description: Compared with women, male drivers of cars and vans were involved in twice as many fatal accidents.
content: Women tend to be better drivers than men — much better, judging by the number of deaths they cause on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
title: It Calls Itself the Energy Capital. Now It Faces 2 ‘Horrifying’ Crises.
description: Houston has been reeling from oil-market chaos on top of a coronavirus shutdown. Job losses could reach 300,000.
content: HOUSTON — On the same day that the price for U.S. crude oil fell to about $30 below zero — a mind-bending concept and the first time oil prices had ever turned negative — Mayor Sylvester Turner of Houston, the self-proclaimed energy capital of the world, stood before reporters. His words were grim and muffled by the black mask covering his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: After Closing for the Virus, Is Michelin Moving Too Quickly?
description: The tire maker’s C.E.O. says the company must be ready for the end of quarantine, but French unions are wary.
content: PARIS — On a recent weekday, while France was still under one of Europe’s tightest lockdowns, mammoth six-foot tractor tires were rolling off the assembly line at a Michelin factory in northeast France. Farther south, other Michelin plants turned out tires for ambulances and fire trucks as fast as small skeleton crews could make them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michaelangelo Matos
title: Remembering Mike Huckaby, a Towering Figure in Detroit House Music
description: The widely beloved D.J., producer and booster championed the sounds of his hometown and served as a trusted tastemaker, in Michigan and around the globe.
content: The death of the Detroit house-music D.J. and producer Mike Huckaby on Friday, at 54, sent a shock wave through the music community he called home. Huckaby — who died from complications of a stroke and Covid-19 at Beaumont Hospital in Detroit’s Royal Oak suburb — was one of global dance music’s most widely beloved figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $700,000 Homes in California
description: A condo in a former Masonic temple in Long Beach, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
content: After sitting empty for a number of years, this 1927 Greek Revival building was converted into condominiums in 2005, and two additional towers were added to form a complex. This unit, on the top level of the 1927 building, has a number of original architectural features, including an exposed-brick wall and a skylight over the oligarch sleeping loft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Lowy
title: Reveling in the Enigmatic Beauty of Easter Island
description: Some 2,200 miles off the coast of Chile, Rapa Nui, also known as Easter Island, is among the world’s most remote — and mysterious — inhabited islands.
content: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Benjamin Lowy shares a collection of photographs from Easter Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matti Friedman
title: The Last Remnants of the Israeli Left
description: If you seek the socialist vision of this country’s founders, it’s no longer in the Knesset — it’s on the wall.
content: MA’ALEH HA-HAMISHA, Israel — In a modest building at this kibbutz in the hills outside Jerusalem, brawny workers in strong colors labor across three high walls, breaking rocks and plowing dark earth. Forgotten, then rediscovered, they’ve been here since 1953. They stare back at you, confident and grave, like saints in a medieval church. They want to tell you something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Erin Schaff
title: ‘Possible Covid’: Why the Lulls Never Last for Weary E.M.S. Crews
description: New York’s ambulance workers have weathered the peak of the coronavirus epidemic, but their ordeal is not over yet.
content: For seven and a half hours, the two New York City paramedics had worked a surprisingly normal shift: a few people with difficulty breathing, one trip to the hospital — and, miraculously it seemed, no clear cases of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Hiroko Masuike
title: Small Business, Texas, Vaccine: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
title: New York Board of Elections Cancels Democratic Presidential Primary
description: The State Board of Elections scrapped the state’s June 23 Democratic nominating contest, citing the risk of spreading coronavirus, in a move opposed by supporters of Bernie Sanders.
content: New York officials canceled the state’s Democratic presidential primary on Monday, prompting an immediate backlash from the campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders and his legion of progressive supporters who had hoped to amass convention delegates and help shape the party’s platform in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Rothkopf
title: Films to Heal a Broken Moment
description: These characters find reasons to carry on in the face of hardship or crisis — examples that can help in our own difficult time.
content: As endings go, the one invented by the Swedish director Lukas Moodysson for his gentle, unassuming comedy “Together” (2001) is just about perfect. It’s not a spoiler to share it: Already, the members of a 1975 commune have squabbled over everything from eating meat to owning a TV and the need for wearing underwear in the kitchen. Their children, often the most mature people in the room, look on, mortified. One morning after the worst of the infighting has ended, everybody heads outside for a sloppy, impromptu soccer match under a light snowfall — adults and kids, women and men, socialists and materialists. In the chaos of the game, all is forgiven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Beaches: A (Photo) Study in Contrasts
description: Monday: The weekend’s heat wave may be a window into the future. Also: A talk with Marin County’s health officer, and the closure of the Noriega Hotel.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Brooklyn Kitchen Takes Its Cooking Classes Online

Farther south, other Michelin plants turned out tires for ambulances and fire trucks as fast as small skeleton crews could make them.

title: Small Business, Texas, Vaccine: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Confident That Rumors of Kim Jong-un Illness Are Wrong
description: Comments by the country’s unification minister represent the South’s most categorical rebuttal of reports that the North’s leader may be incapacitated.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea is confident that there is no basis to the recent swirl of rumors that the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ​is gravely ill, ​the South’s chief policymaker on the North​ said in comments reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: In Kayleigh McEnany, Trump Taps a Press Fighter for the Coronavirus Era
description: Kayleigh McEnany saw Donald J. Trump as her ticket to stardom. She has been fighting for him for much of her adult life, now as the president’s fourth press secretary.
content: WASHINGTON — Kayleigh McEnany was a Harvard law student at a Manhattan rooftop cocktail party in the summer of 2015 when a colleague awakened her to the opportunity that was Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins, Michael Rothfeld, William K. Rashbaum and Brian M. Rosenthal
title: Top E.R. Doctor Who Treated Virus Patients Dies by Suicide
description: “She tried to do her job, and it killed her,” said the father of Dr. Lorna M. Breen, who worked at a Manhattan hospital hit hard by the coronavirus outbreak.
content: A top emergency room doctor at a Manhattan hospital that treated many coronavirus patients died by suicide on Sunday, her father and the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
title: Soccer Coach in El Paso Shooting Dies 9 Months Later
description: A soccer coach whose extensive injuries kept him hospitalized died nearly nine months after the shooting, the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history.
content: HOUSTON — A soccer coach who was among those shot at a Walmart in El Paso last year in the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history has died nearly nine months later, bringing the death toll from the shooting to 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and David McCabe
title: Start-Ups Pursue ‘Free Money’ With Relief Funds, Prompting Backlash
description: Some young companies have turned to the government loans not for day-to-day survival but simply to buy useful time.
content: Domio, a start-up that offers short-term rentals, has its headquarters in a New York City loft that features beer on tap, a game room and a wall of house slippers for visitors. The fast-growing and unprofitable company has raised $117 million in venture capital, including $100 million in August.
source.name: The New York Times
